---
title:  "Modelling disease mortality"
date:   2020-01-30 10:00:00 +0000
categories: ["stats", "Bayes by dummies"]
---

<title>2020-01-30-modelling-disease-with-binomial.utf8</title>










</head>

<body>







<p><a href="https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/446912/is-there-a-model-to-predict-mortality-rate-of-an-ongoing-epidemic/446923">A recent post</a> on CrossValidated interested me, so I wrote a bit of an explainer on how one might model the mortality rate of a disease. I ended up writing a bit of an essay by mistake, so I’m reposting it here for posterity. Also, I’ve only gotten two votes for a post that took 30 minutes or so, while I got 6 on StackOverflow for copy/pasting an R help page in 10 seconds, so I’m a little bit salty.</p>
<p>They asked:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Following the recent Coronavirus outbreak, various mortality rates have been published.<br />
Most of these are simply the ratio between the deaths and the total verified cases, which is not a very accurate indicator as many of the verified cases are ongoing and could result in deaths.<br />
I know some statistics from university but I am in no way an expert. I was wondering if there was any commonly used statistical model to predict with some accuracy the mortality rate of an ongoing epidemic. If there is, I’m guessing some of the variables would be the time between the onsetting of symptoms and death/healing for resolved cases.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>A natural (and perhaps naive) way to model mortality would be a binomial model, i.e.,</p>
<p><span class="math display">\[
x \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)
\]</span></p>
<p>Here <span class="math inline">\(x\)</span> is the number of deaths, <span class="math inline">\(n\)</span> is the total number of people infected, and <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span> is the mortality rate, or the probability of dying given that you have the disease. When we say something is distributed according to a binomial distribution, we mean that the observed counts <span class="math inline">\(x\)</span> are the result of <span class="math inline">\(n\)</span> independent trials, each with probability of “success” (in this case, death) <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span>. These are usually termed “Bernoulli trials”.</p>
<p>We can now examine the likelihood of <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span> given <span class="math inline">\(x\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(n\)</span> – i.e., how likely it would be to see the data we have observed, given different values of <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span>. Imagine we had 100 cases, 50 of which resulted in deaths:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>n &lt;- 100
x &lt;- 50
s &lt;- seq(0, 1, length.out=1000)
plot(
  s, dbinom(x, size = n, prob = s), type=&quot;l&quot;,
  xlab = &quot;Mortality rate (p)&quot;, ylab = &quot;Binomial likelihood&quot;
)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
<!-- ![](https://i.imgur.com/nhnboC4.png) -->
<p>This shows that a point estimate (the maximum likelihood estimate) would be 0.5, which of course makes sense. Something important to consider here is the amount of data we have observed. Since we have a good amount of observations, the likelihood is fairly narrow. This means that there is a relatively small range of values for <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span> for which the data we observed would be likely to occur.</p>
<p>Now, imagine if we had only 10 cases, 5 of which resulted in deaths:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>x &lt;- 5
n &lt;- 10
s &lt;- seq(0, 1, length.out=1000)
plot(
  s, dbinom(x, size = n, prob = s), type=&quot;l&quot;,
  xlab = &quot;Mortality rate (p)&quot;, ylab = &quot;Binomial likelihood&quot;
)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /> <!-- ![](https://i.imgur.com/b7RXHx4.png) --></p>
<p>When we don’t have much information, the likelihood is quite broad, indicating that the data would be fairly likely for a wide range of values for <span class="math inline">\(p\)</span>.</p>
<p>It can be helpful in cases like this to incorporate a prior, or how likely we think different parameter values are, based on our existing knowledge. For example, imagine that we knew that the distribution of mortality rates across all known human diseases looked something like this:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>s &lt;- seq(0, 1, length.out=1000)
plot(
  s, dbeta(s, 32, 64), type=&quot;l&quot;,
  xlab = &quot;Mortality rate (p)&quot;, ylab = &quot;Proportion of diseases&quot;
)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /> <!-- ![](https://i.imgur.com/O1b7Jrn.png) --></p>
<p>This is a Beta prior with <span class="math inline">\(\alpha=32\)</span> and <span class="math inline">\(\beta=64\)</span>, i.e., $ p (32, 64)$. We might want to use this prior information to guide our inferences about the mortality rate of a new disease for which we have very little information. We can combine this prior information with the likelihoods we’ve already plotted. If you want details about how this is done, one great starting point is <a href="http://varianceexplained.org/r/empirical_bayes_baseball/">this blog by David Robinson</a>. Basically, the posterior distribution over our parameters is a Beta distribution. For parameters we take the <span class="math inline">\(\alpha\)</span> of our prior and add <span class="math inline">\(x\)</span> (the number of deaths), and take the <span class="math inline">\(\beta\)</span> of our prior and add <span class="math inline">\(n-x\)</span> (the number of people who have had the disease but not died).</p>
<pre class="r"><code>s &lt;- seq(0, 1, length.out=1000)
n &lt;- 100
x &lt;- 50
plot(
  s, dbeta(s, shape1 = 32 + x, shape2 = 64 + n - x), 
  type=&quot;l&quot;, xlab = &quot;Mortality rate (p)&quot;, ylab = &quot;Posterior density&quot;
)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /> <!-- ![](https://i.imgur.com/1F8HpSv.png) --></p>
<p>As you can see, this prior information “pulls” our estimates downwards towards the distribution of existing mortality rates. However, if we had strong enough evidence (for example, thousands of infections and deaths) we could still produce an estimate outside of where the prior distribution is concentrated. When we have a small amount of data, a prior can be particularly helpful to avoid results that are purely the result of sampling noise - for example, imagine the first 10 people with a disease happen to die, and the next 90 survive. The estimate after 10 people would be 100%, which is extremely unlikely, given what we’ve seen about human disease in the past.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>s &lt;- seq(0, 1, length.out=1000)
n &lt;- 10
x &lt;- 5
plot(
  s, dbeta(s, shape1 = 32 + x, shape2 = 64 + n - x),
  type=&quot;l&quot;, xlab = &quot;Mortality rate (p)&quot;, ylab = &quot;Posterior density&quot;
)</code></pre>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /> <!-- ![](https://i.imgur.com/yV8QGZT.png) --></p>
<p>When we have very little data, this prior information really shrinks our estimates towards what we believe is a reasonable estimate of mortality, given what we’ve observed in the past about other diseases.</p>
<p>You can continually update this posterior distribution as new data comes in by adding deaths to the <span class="math inline">\(\alpha\)</span> parameter and survivals to the <span class="math inline">\(\beta\)</span> parameter of the Beta distribution.</p>
<p>This is all just general; I have no real expertise in disease modelling. None of the parameters values I’ve chosen have any basis in reality.</p>
